name: NPR
text:
Mei Xiang, the 22-year-old panda at the Smithsonian's National Zoo, has given birth to a male cub.

Mama Panda "is caring for her newborn attentively," zoo officials said.
https://t.co/ldF3Y4txDn

name: NPR
text:
RT @NPRItsBeenAMin: “[This] nation is founded out of a culture that is deeply conflicted about whether that's the sort of democracy we want to become,” @marthasjones_ tells @samsanders about voting and power in the United States.

More of their chat: https://t.co/RwLimlVMqz https://t.co/Dy8Eh1KnaI

name: NPR
text:
Mei Xiang, the 22-year-old panda at the Smithsonian's National Zoo, has given birth to a cub.

Mama Panda "is caring for her newborn attentively," zoo officials said.
https://t.co/uJvch21rdf

name: NPR
text: A previous tweet said the newborn is male. In fact, it's not yet possible to determine the sex.

name: NPR
text: .@WBUR asked readers and contributors — parents and teachers, students and administrators, physicians and epidemiologists — to tell us how they’re managing as students go back to school. This is their story in their words. https://t.co/FJiJvKkWJ7

name: NPR
text:
Gov. Gavin Newsom says raging fires in California have burned an area the size of Rhode Island, with little relief in sight. "We simply haven't seen anything like this in many, many years."
https://t.co/2Vxv2J4M8E

name: NPR
text: Romance columnist Maya Rodale rounds up three historical novels featuring heroines on a mission — and love interests who'll stand up for them, no matter what troubles come. https://t.co/IpwPnAwoF4

name: NPR
text:
A geologist has discovered a pair of fossil footprints that researchers say are the oldest of their kind in the Grand Canyon — dating back 313 million years.
https://t.co/QleuyNyBuL

name: NPR
text:
School nurses in LA are planning to help test more than 600,000 students and 75,000 staff members for COVID-19 — and will implement contact tracing techniques to prevent the virus's spread.

"Is it going to be mind boggling? It could be."
https://t.co/MPcLqXGHfh

name: NPR
text:
The Trump administration has struck a small-scale trade agreement with the E.U. agreeing to suspend tariffs on imports of live and frozen lobster from the U.S. for at least 5 years.
https://t.co/ybxuaEb7K3

name: NPR
text:
A campaign dubbed "CinemaSafe" aims to ease moviegoer's fears, featuring industry-wide health and safety protocols. "It's important to understand that going to the movies is not risk-free," says one epidemiologist.
https://t.co/pjtogEweKp

name: NPR
text:
Cuban-American pop star Gloria Estefan's latest album, "Brazil305," is a reexamination of some of her most familiar songs through the lens of her lifelong love of Brazilian music and rhythms. 

More from @AltLatino⤵️
https://t.co/8KWpZamIRj

name: NPR
text:
Each year, 1.2 million Filipina girls between the ages of 10 and 19 have a child. That's a rate of 24 babies per hour.

The government has been trying to change that statistic — but the pandemic made matters worse. 
https://t.co/IO6f3BFzw2

name: NPR
text:
Maya Shankar was well on her way to a career as a violinist when an injury closed that door. 

@HiddenBrain revisits a conversation with Maya, in which she shares how she found a new path forward after losing an identity she loved. https://t.co/Ttw6bbAI6t

name: NPR
text: In 2018, LeBron James opened the I Promise school in Akron, Ohio for at-risk kids. In his new children's book of the same name, James calls upon kids everywhere to be their best selves. https://t.co/FODZHXDHrU

name: NPR
text:
The secret to waterproof waterfowl, it turns out, lies in their feathers. (@KQEDScience)
https://t.co/O3W3rJ6MLx

name: NPR
text:
Ricardo “Papu” Ovilla came to the U.S. during World War II as part of the Bracero Program. He became a U.S. citizen, but his granddaughters say his fear of deportation never subsided.

He always kept his passport on him — even on trips to the supermarket. https://t.co/GTTn5PhM13

name: NPR
text: The historical documentary "Coup 53" tells the story of Operation Ajax, in which Britain's MI6 and the American CIA planned the forcible removal of Iran's prime minister in 1953. A live, transatlantic digital release of the film will take place on Aug. 19. https://t.co/yKvRZUsvD7

name: NPR
text: RT @NPRWeekend: In just a few minutes... our most delightful story of the day! https://t.co/ic2HxvzXOi

name: NPR
text:
Experts said first-time absentee voters are much more likely to make the kinds of mistakes that lead to rejected ballots.

That raises alarms for November, when tens of millions of more voters are expected to vote by mail — many for the first time. https://t.co/JoSKSsuGlw

name: NPR
text:
Most absentee or mail-in ballots are rejected because:

• required signatures are missing 
• signatures don't match the one on record 
• the ballot arrives too late https://t.co/xgPwKPuAog

name: NPR
text:
In more than half the states, Democrats are in court fighting to extend mail-in ballot deadlines and to waive witness and notary requirements.

They also want voters to be allowed to fix errors before their ballots are rejected. https://t.co/xgPwKPuAog

name: NPR
text:
These differences will likely be exacerbated in November when turnout is much higher.

"If you have 1% of maybe up… https://t.co/os35g50fLR

name: NPR
text:
That could not only affect the outcome of the presidential election but other races as well. 

In 2018 in Florida, Republican Rick Scott beat incumbent Democrat Bill Nelson for the Senate by just over 10,000 votes. https://t.co/xgPwKPuAog
